Quantum theory is a highly successful and elegant way of describing the physical world. However, it is not a theory in the ordinary sense of the word, in that it is not based on a formal axiomatic system. This has led to a number of attempts to provide a foundation for quantum theory, and in particular to find a mathematical structure that is equivalent to the category of linear operators on the complex numbers, the category of complex Hilbert spaces, and the category of complex C*-algebras. We provide such an axiomatization, which is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. Our results have implications for the foundations of quantum theory and for the reconstruction of quantum theory from a possible foundation.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two myxozoan species and the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the cnidarian parasite P. hydriforme and that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme genome reduction. Our findings suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Read more)

The ability of viruses to evade host defense mechanisms is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host antiviral response and may help to design new antiviral strategies against COVID-19. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of the proton channel. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits the proton channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the proton channel. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain production will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is virtually zero today, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of species matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the coexistence of species, and suggest that the role of large mammals in African savanna biodiversity may be more complex than previously thought. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is uncertain, and many businesses expect to remain open for some time. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. These findings have implications for policymakers and small businesses alike.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system and the early solar system. We studied the age of the solar system by measuring the exposure age of presolar silicon carbide grains. The results show that the solar system is ∼4.6 Ga old, which is consistent with the age of the oldest solar system material.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase reproductive output is a defining characteristic of all animals. In this study, we show that the ability to increase reproductive output is also a defining characteristic of animals that have been domesticated or that have evolved allomaternal care. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the mother’s metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is the mother’s metabolic power. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care and may lead to the development of new reproductive technologies. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care and may lead to the development of new reproductive technologies.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic candidate for MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA. The results also suggest that caspase-1 could be a potential therapeutic target in MSA and other synucleinopathies. Finally, the results provide a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies. This study opens the door to the development of a new therapeutic strategy for MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the primary interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary site of communication between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels and the hemostasis of the blood. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control these functions by processing information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate the information from multiple sources and control the functions of the blood vessels. The communication system is found to be highly effective in controlling the functions of the blood vessels.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and we hope that the API will empower research and decision-making. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders, including public health researchers, epidemiologists, and policy makers. We hope that the API will be useful to all.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the transport of potassium ions. The selectivity filter is also the site of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the inactivation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and that its substitution with Alanine leads to the loss of C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we have shown that the collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter is a key step in the process of inactivation. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanism of potassium channels and may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of diseases involving potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the host environment. In this study, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These fungi are important to consider in the context of the microbiome because they are abundant in the gut, and because they are a potential source of natural products that could be used to treat infections.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens may be a marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety

The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and fabricate structures that seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of the least constraint. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and fabrication of mechanical devices with desired behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a major regulator of the human body’s oxygen carrying capacity. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein is expressed in the human erythroid lineage and that IGF2BP1 mediates the let-7-dependent down-regulation of the adult hemoglobin system and the up-regulation of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest that the let-7 miRNA pathway may be involved in the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is a recently discovered form of regulated cell death that is dysregulated in cancer, and its inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy. However, the mechanisms of ferroptosis are not fully understood, and the clinical utility of ferroptosis-inducing agents is not yet established. Here, we show that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through SREBP1/SCD1-mediated lipogenesis. We also show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in ferroptosis resistance, and they suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving STIM1 and ORAI1. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling should be carefully considered. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but that the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations accelerated. This finding is important because the NWFP was based on science and incorporated adaptive management. Our results suggest that the NWFP was not successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, and that the policy needs to be revised to ensure the conservation of these species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the rational design of new antibiotics. The design strategy presented here can be applied to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for the treatment of infectious diseases. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with large datasets. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that can be trained with a small number of images. The proposed network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. This makes the proposed architecture more suitable for applications that require training with a small number of images.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin and phase-delays the circadian clock, with important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth system. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The Os in the spherules is likely terrestrially derived, and the source of the Os in the spherules is from the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os in the spherules is consistent with the Os in the magnetic grains and microspherules, suggesting that the magnetic grains and microspherules are ejecta from an impact.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is still not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We also show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity induced by adoptive transfer of T cells. These findings indicate that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for the maintenance of tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which is a key process in the evolution of beetles. Our analyses suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These findings have implications for our understanding of the origin of beetle diversity and the evolution of plant-feeding habits. They also suggest that the evolution of beetles may be more closely linked to the evolution of plants than previously thought.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also provide a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning in the engineering of other protein molecules. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of the size of the population. This may have important implications for the evolution of human societies.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,500 km in radius and has a density of 12.0–12.5 g/cm3. It is the densest solid in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than the nucleation of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is not a single homogeneous body but consists of several domains with different crystal structures. This study provides a new perspective on the origin of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are attenuated in marijuana abusers. The attenuated responses are associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the attenuated brain responses to methylphenidate may contribute to the addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. The findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

We present a large-scale, data-driven investigation of the neural basis of language processing in the human brain. We show that the most accurate machine-learning models for this task also explain the majority of the data’s variance. This suggests that the models are capturing the key mechanisms by which people understand language. We find that model architecture is strongly associated with model performance, suggesting that certain types of models are particularly well-suited to this task. These results provide computational support for the idea that language comprehension in the human brain is a form of predictive processing. Understanding the mechanisms of language comprehension has been a central goal of cognitive science for over a century. We believe that this work moves us closer to understanding the brain’s signature cognitive skill.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL is a special case of a more general problem, which is well-posed. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing that are well-posed, but there are no algorithms that can solve them. This result has implications for the field of deep learning, as well as for the field of scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. One of the most cited studies in the psychology of misinformation, the “foot-in-the-door” experiment, is often cited as evidence that people are unable to process exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed, and that its conclusion is based on a misunderstanding of the experiment’s results. We discuss the implications of this case study for the study of misinformation and for the interpretation of psychological research in general.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia, and its history is intertwined with the development of modern medicine. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense study for more than a century, and its genome sequence is now available. In contrast, the identity of the pathogen causing the rare and poorly understood reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon has been unknown. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, the causative agent of lepromatous leprosy, and show that it is more closely related to the leprosy pathogen than is M. leprae. This finding suggests that the two pathogens have retained many of the same functions for more than 13 million years. This work provides a unique opportunity to study the evolution of leprosy and to understand the mechanisms that underlie the development of reactional leprosy. (Read more)

The evolution of entanglement is a fundamental question in quantum mechanics. It is also a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nontrivial problem, which has so far been solved only for noninteracting systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the interacting system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a highly nontrivial task. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also provides a new perspective on the entanglement dynamics in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The development of a safe and effective vaccine is the only way to end the pandemic. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive, and the attenuated virus grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate induces high levels of spike IgG antibodies and plaque reduction neutralization titers, and it protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C, which makes it suitable for mass vaccination programs. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising candidate for the fight against COVID-19. (Read more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is poorly understood. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasite vectors, which fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of brain size and neuron number in amniotes, which are the animals that include birds and mammals. We show that the evolution of brain size and neuron number is not independent but rather is linked by a set of evolutionary changes. These changes are important for understanding the evolution of brain size and cognition. We also discuss the implications of our results for studies that use relative brain size as a proxy for cognitive ability.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key process in many cellular processes, including cell migration and cytokinesis. However, the mechanism by which ADF severes filaments is not well understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is enhanced by mechanical forces. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of mechanical forces in severing and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for actin-based diseases. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. In addition, the findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also have implications for understanding the effects of fasting versus feeding on brain and behavior. Finally, the findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. These findings may help explain the increased risk of obesity and diabetes associated with fructose consumption. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also highlight the importance of considering the spatial resolution of the sampling when studying the human population history of an island. This article is protected by copyright. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred from one person to another. We show that this effect is not limited to in-person interaction, and that it is not limited to positive emotions. This work suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the emotional content of the social network may have a significant impact on the emotional state of its users. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of emotional contagion in general. They also suggest that the emotional content of social networks may have a significant impact on the emotional state of its users.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of mRNA modifications can alter the structure and function of the RNA, and thus, the proteins that are synthesized. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can alter the rate of translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have subtle effects on the translation of the RNA. This study provides insight into the role of Ψ in mRNA structure and function. It also provides a foundation for future studies that will explore the impact of Ψ on mRNA translation in vivo. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships, and that this association is independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain optimal use of time at older ages. This may be particularly important in the context of the rapidly aging population, and may be a target for interventions to improve the quality of life at older ages. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This study provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on mammalian body size and the evolution of aquatic lifestyles. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of mammalian body size and the role of aquatic lifestyles in driving the evolution of larger body size.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the temperature at which it replicates in the nasal cavity is cooler than the core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study provides insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus, which may be relevant to the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of the common cold.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is based on the observation that type IV pili are involved in surface attachment and that the pili are required for the surface-induced regulation of virulence. Our results demonstrate that the type IV pili are also involved in sensing surfaces, and that the pili are directly involved in the regulation of the surface-induced regulation of virulence. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of bacterial motility systems and for the development of new antibacterial strategies.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the exposure of surface waters to particularly toxic agricultural insecticides. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global pesticide situation and is a first step toward a better understanding of the effects of pesticides on the environment.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been documented in a variety of animal species, including bats, pigs, and a variety of wildlife species. However, the role of these species in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 to humans is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, the most abundant cervid in North America. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 RNA is present in deer during the winter months, when human cases are at their peak. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions. The paper also examines the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary component of the pathological process. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still controversial. Here, we show that Aβ is not the only factor that triggers the immune response in the brain. We demonstrate that soluble Aβ species are toxic to neurons, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is not the only factor that triggers the immune response in the brain. We also show that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is not the only factor that triggers the immune response in the brain.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. Our faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, provides the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens. We show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread in the Southern Levant during the Hellenistic period and that the species was fully integrated into the local economy by the first century B.C.E. This is a crucial step in the adoption of chickens in European husbandry some 100 y later.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is also inactivated by stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme for Np4-capped RNAs. We demonstrate that RppH decaps Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decaps other RNAs, and that this enzyme requires a second deprotection step to generate the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate RNA decay. Our findings suggest that the stress response in bacteria is more complex than previously thought, and that the role of Np4 in stress adaptation may be more extensive than previously thought. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that arginine, a major amino acid in the diet, is a key molecule in the regulation of T cell function during sepsis. We demonstrate that arginine is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation and that its deficiency leads to lymphopenia, Treg expansion, and MDSC accumulation. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve immune function after sepsis. Further studies are needed to test this hypothesis in humans. (Read more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a critical rate, which is independent of the rate at which it is controlled. SOC systems are ubiquitous in nature and are of great interest to scientists. However, the mathematical description of SOC systems is still in its infancy. In this paper, we present a mathematical model of SOC, which is a continuous version of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, which requires further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum applications. However, it is not a perfect material, and its properties can be improved by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and we provide a pathway to metallization in six-dimensional strain space. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly through strain engineering, and we provide a pathway to demetallization in six-dimensional strain space. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is still elusive. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, from Medicago truncatula. This peptide is structurally unique, with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. NCR044 exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and its mode of action was revealed by structural and functional studies. The antifungal activity of NCR044 was demonstrated by spraying it on plants, and it was shown to be effective against gray mold disease caused by Botrytis cinerea. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of using them as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This approach could be useful in the management of plant fungal diseases. (Read more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the sperm changes substantially after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins to support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and the public interested in the origin of life. (Read more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF is able to switch between two states, one of which is more effective at binding platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWF and provides a target for therapeutic intervention.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for the human virome, which can be used to study the human microbiome in a more holistic way. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and diseases. The results of this study provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that this instrument will provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This will help us to improve climate models and, ultimately, to improve our understanding of the climate system. This will also help us to improve our ability to predict the climate system.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life, as it is a key factor in the evolution of the biosphere. The temperature of the surface has been inferred from isotopic data, but this has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. This study demonstrates the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 627,000 deaths in 2017 alone. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has been the subject of intense study for over a century. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the disease process and opens up new avenues for therapeutic intervention. (Read more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum applications. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is difficult to use diamond in applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be closed, without breaking. This finding opens up opportunities to use diamond in applications. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical sensor. This finding opens up opportunities to use diamond in sensing applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s activity during the construction of such a tree remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a tree-like structure of phrases increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words merge into phrases. This decrease in activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This work may help to explain the brain’s ability to process language, and it may also provide a starting point for the development of new technologies for the treatment of language disorders.

The Wnt pathway is one of the most important signaling pathways in development and homeostasis. It is also involved in the development of cancer. The pathway is regulated by a complex network of proteins, and the understanding of this network is still incomplete. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently, and that this difference is used to regulate the two forms of Axin differently. This is an example of a subtle difference that may be used to regulate redundant genes in a tissue-specific manner.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH GABA neurons induces vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system, suggesting that dopamine may be involved in the regulation of feeding. However, stimulation-induced eating is not blocked by lesions of the dopamine system in the ventral tegmental area, suggesting that a second pathway may be involved. We show that stimulation of LH GABA terminals in the caudal LH or stimulation of GABA neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus induce eating. These results suggest that LH GABA neurons may promote overeating by activating a dopamine pathway that in turn activates the locus coeruleus, a noradrenergic nucleus that is involved in the regulation of feeding. This circuit may contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. Thus, the development of strategies to increase the efficiency of nitrogen fixation is a key challenge for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal crop. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to increase the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in cereal crops and, ultimately, to increase the sustainability of agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts to communities and training and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. The results also suggest that the effectiveness of such a protocol depends on the ability of the monitors to deter deforestation and that the monitors’ ability to do so depends on the extent to which they are perceived as legitimate authorities.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We estimate that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 (2.96–4.21) million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 (4.52–6.52) million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing the anthropogenic emissions in the model increases rainfall by 10–70% over densely populated regions in India and 10–30% over northern China, and by 10–40% over Central America, West Africa, and the drought-prone Sahel.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccines are needed to protect individuals and to contain the virus. Recombinant subunit vaccines are a proven technology that can be used to rapidly produce billions of doses of vaccine annually. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, and that can be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine. This variant is more immunogenic than the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence used in current vaccines, and can be used to design vaccines that can be used to contain the pandemic. This work provides a potential solution to the global access problem of COVID-19 vaccines. (Read more)

The ALKAL family of secreted proteins is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that the ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and suggest a role of ALKALs in human cancer.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most important events in human history. However, the history of plague is poorly understood because of the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age. We show that plague’s emergence was a long process that involved multiple evolutionary steps and a nonflea-adapted form of plague. We also show that the plague-flea association emerged later, and that the plague-flea form of plague was already present in Bronze Age Iberia. These data provide insights into the early history of plague and its relationship with its vector. (Read more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM predicted evaluations of Trump, across studies, social and prejudiced attitudes predicted evaluations of his democratic challengers: Clinton in 2016 and Biden in 2020. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural systems is a key driver of climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has liberated massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of perennial pastures can sequester C in the soil and that the use of legumes and manure in annual cropping systems can enhance soil health. These findings highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. This work also highlights the importance of soil microbial processes in the fate of C in agricultural systems and the need to understand the role of soil microbial processes in the functioning of agricultural ecosystems. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We developed a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and use the information to inform research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms by which plants produce colored nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insights into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–animal mutualism. (Read more)

We present the genomes of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is also reflected in the collective genetic ancestry of a group of women with artificial skull deformations, who appear to have originated in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Our results also highlight the need for a better understanding of the processes that shaped the genetic history of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid deployment of public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The PCNA sliding clamp is responsible for the formation of a complex with DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) that is essential for the synthesis of the lagging strand. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in the replication of the human genome. This knowledge will be useful in the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and infectious diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life began with the evolution of RNA-based enzymes that replicated genetic information and catalyzed the formation of functional molecules. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the RNA world. We show that RNA polymerase ribozymes can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, and that they can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the experimental reconstruction of the RNA world. It also opens the door to the study of the origin of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of a neighborhood in determining its future physical appearance. This finding has implications for urban planning and design, as well as for the design of computer vision methods for urban studies.
