The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper content and to mediate interactions with competing microbes is therefore an important aspect of their physiology. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus is a model for the evolution of fungal BGCs, and the BGC-derived isocyanide metabolites have been shown to have antimicrobial properties. Here we demonstrate that the BGC is also involved in copper homeostasis, and that the BGC is active in interactions with other fungi and bacteria. These findings suggest that the BGC is a potential source of antifungal and antibacterial metabolites in A. fumigatus, and that the BGC is a potential source of fungal metabolites in interactions with other fungi and bacteria. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal BGCs and the role of metal homeostasis in fungal interactions. (Read more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the region. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sediment suggests that the source of these materials was in the vicinity of the sediment deposition site. The presence of a variety of aqueous-derived precipitates and/or their diagenesis products in the sediment suggests that the region was a depositional environment with variable fluid compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of anhydrite in the sediment suggests that the region was also a site of post-lithification fluid flow. These results provide insights into the nature of the sediment source region and the depositional environment of the laminated mudstone at Buckskin, Gale crater, Mars.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors for plants and animals, and its impact on the ecosystem is often underestimated. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to mitigate the economic losses that can result from the increasing number of late-spring frosts. Our results can also help to predict the impact of frost on other organisms, such as insects and birds, and to assess the vulnerability of the ecosystem to the changes in the frequency of frost events. Our findings can be used to improve the accuracy of climate change impact assessments and to develop mitigation strategies.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms underlying the disease are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapeutics for ALS. This method will also enable the study of the mechanisms of other neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington’s disease. The role of the microbiome in vector competence for infectious agents is a topic of great interest. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its colonization. We demonstrate that the bacterium induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. This perturbation of the microbiota influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, the vector expresses antifreeze glycoprotein, which binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies for vector control. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching members of this group obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the short tail and the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the ability to change color has been used to adapt to the environment.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces breast cancer stem cells, and that this is mediated by HIF-dependent expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase. ALKBH5 expression is increased in response to hypoxia, and this correlates with the enrichment of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. The results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment in the past and the source of the skins used in the production of modern parchment. This would be of interest to codicologists, conservators, and the general public.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, but the timing of the extinction is well established. The age model for the extinction is, however, based on a single radiometric date, and the age of the mass extinction is poorly constrained. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction, based on five volcanic ash beds, and demonstrate that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya. This age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This work will also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results will have important implications for our understanding of the causes and consequences of mass extinctions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) in mice. We find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for therapeutic antibodies. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in the virus population, and several studies have suggested that it is associated with higher infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the D614G and G614 mutant states and show that the mutant spike is more open and that this may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to design therapeutic antibodies and vaccines. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) for finite games. Our result is also a step toward the study of the computational complexity of finding an ε-equilibrium in repeated games. We show that the problem is hard to approximate within a factor of n−ε, for any fixed ε>0, in the class of alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This is the first hardness result for this problem.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.08 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of matter are the basis of chemistry. The chemical properties of matter are also the basis of the periodic table, which is the most powerful tool in chemistry. The periodic table is a powerful tool for predicting the properties of elements, but it is based on the assumption that chemical properties are constant. We show that chemical properties are not constant, but change with pressure. This finding has implications for the periodic table, and for the understanding of the origin of the periodic table. It also has implications for the understanding of the origin of the chemical bond, and for the understanding of the origin of the chemical element. It also has implications for the understanding of the origin of life.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, such as population growth and migration, can have a large effect on fire activity, and that this can have a significant impact on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that changes in human demography can reduce warming by up to 10 y at today’s levels. This highlights the importance of human activities in driving fire regimes and the need to consider the role of human activities in climate mitigation strategies. Our study also highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle, and the need to consider fire in climate models and in climate mitigation strategies.

The symbiosis between animals and microbes is one of the most ancient and widespread forms of life on Earth. The mutualistic partners, however, are often very different in terms of size, physiology, and biochemistry. This study shows that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a key factor in the establishment and maintenance of the symbiosis. The glycan is provided by the host only at night, when the symbiont is active, and its catabolism is required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-mediated regulation of the symbiont’s activity may be a common mechanism of host control over the activities of symbiotic microbes in other animal-microbe associations. This study provides a new perspective on the symbiosis between animals and microbes, and it may lead to the development of new approaches for the control of microbial infections. (Read more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show that we can identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and to explore the gendered nature of these patterns. This can lead to a better understanding of the world around us.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate change in the spread of infectious diseases. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including sea stars. Here, we provide evidence that a densovirus is the cause of a disease that has led to the mass mortality of asteroids. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a disease in asteroids. The findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of viruses in the functioning of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapeutic intervention is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that the antibodies can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the results presented here provide a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AML. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and of the human settlement of the Indian Ocean. They also provide a better understanding of the human history of Africa, and of the role of the Indian Ocean in the dispersal of people and cultures. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19.

We show that the information provided by crop experts can be used to produce a continuous and quantitative measure of crop status, which can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict crop yields. Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. This adaptive change in excitability is a form of memory that can be accessed directly without the need for cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language and its development. It is important to note that this model is not intended to be a complete account of language. Rather, it is a first step toward a more complete model that can be tested in the future.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work highlights the need for further research to elucidate the response of soil respiration to warming in a variety of ecosystems. (Read more)

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is thought to have occurred in the last common ancestor of the plastid-containing lineages, which is the origin of the majority of the extant photosynthetic organisms. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the relaxation of functional constraints is linked to the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle. This evolutionary trajectory may be relevant to the origin of the plastid genome and its evolution.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional climate modeling for understanding the impact of climate change on water resources. This work provides a useful tool for water resource managers and policy makers in SSA. (Abridged)

The first nuclear explosion, tested in the desert of New Mexico on 16 July 1945, released an amount of energy equivalent to 20,000 tons of TNT. This event is widely regarded as the beginning of the nuclear age. The explosion also produced a glassy material, trinitite, which was formed by the fusion of sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the trinitite. This discovery provides a link between the past and the present, and it demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by extreme pressure–temperature conditions, and that they can be found in the most unexpected places.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which life on Earth is sustained. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the capture of light by pigments, which are modified tetrapyrroles. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key step in this process, and has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we identified ASK1 as a key regulator of neuroinflammation in EAE. We found that ASK1 is required for the early and later stages of neuroinflammation in microglia/macrophages. ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes and microglia/macrophages, but not in T cells and dendritic cells, reduced disease severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in EAE. These results also suggest that ASK1 may be a potential therapeutic target for neurodegenerative diseases.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities. This finding has important implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation. It suggests that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase in the future, and that the probability of drought will increase if warming continues unabated. Thus, the probability of drought will increase in the future, and adaptation efforts should focus on reducing the probability of drought. Autism is a complex disorder with a large genetic component. The genetic basis of autism is so complicated that it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and its dysregulation is associated with a variety of diseases. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and STIM2 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and in patients with Stormorken syndrome, we find that these mutations result in bleeding diathesis and thrombocytopenia. We also identify ORAI1 mutations that result in a similar phenotype, and show that these mutations affect the function of the CRAC channel. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of the dysregulation of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that the aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. These findings suggest that the spread of aggregates is a key element of the disease process and that the internalization of aggregates may be a therapeutic target. This work provides a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, which we named Myotis pilosus protein (MP), potently inhibited the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MP-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon pool is a critical metabolic substrate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, which blocks colon cancer cell growth. We also report the discovery of a new class of glycine transporter inhibitors, which may be useful in the treatment of lymphoma. These studies provide a foundation for the development of new therapeutics for cancer and lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS are a consequence of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may provide a new target for therapeutic intervention. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be broadly applicable to the design of photonic devices for quantum materials and quantum matter. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in the fields of quantum materials, quantum matter, and photonic devices.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of Spain more than 100 y ago. This plant has been poorly understood in the past, and its position in the evolution of the flowering plants has been controversial. The research presented here provides a detailed analysis of Montsechia, which shows that it is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is the sister to the Ceratophyllum clade. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in virology, but it is difficult to study because of the short time that viruses have been alive compared to the time that life has been on Earth. Here we show that the human pathogen parvovirus B19 has been associated with humans for at least 12.6 kya, and that it has been evolving at a much slower rate than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been infecting humans for a long time, and that we should be aware of the potential effects of human activities on the evolution of viruses. Finally, it shows that the human pathogen B19V is not the only virus that has been associated with humans for a long time.

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is in agreement with the rate of sea level rise reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in its Fifth Assessment Report. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the rate of acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of the Earth’s climate. This finding is important because it suggests that the rate of sea level rise is not a lagging indicator of climate change but instead is a leading indicator of climate change. This finding has implications for the design of coastal protection and adaptation strategies.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of the middle class.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir is effective in preventing disease, and in reducing the severity of disease if treatment is initiated after infection. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS patients. Remdesivir may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronavirus infections. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a model for the study of host–microbe interactions. Here we show that the squid provides a single glycan, chitin, to its symbionts cyclically, at dusk, and that this glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts in the squid’s crypts. We propose that this glycan-mediated regulation of the symbiont population is a general mechanism used by hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. This mechanism may be particularly important in the case of symbiotic organisms that are associated with epithelial tissues, where the host’s control over the symbiont population may be critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the immune regulation of symbionts. (Read more)

Suspension rates in US schools are high, and the consequences of suspension are severe. This study tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed through a scalable intervention. Teachers in three districts (Nteachers = 31; Nstudents = 1,682) were randomized to a brief, online intervention that encouraged them to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. Evaluated at five middle schools, the intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of school discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. Here, we report the results from a systematic investigation of the effects of alkylation on transcription. We found that the presence of alkylation can alter the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and the transcriptional lesion bypass routes. The results from this study provide important mechanistic insights into the effects of alkylation on transcription. This work also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is the latest member of the coronavirus family to emerge, and it is the first to cause severe human disease. The virus is zoonotic, and therefore, it is important to understand how MERS-CoV infects humans. Here, we show that the first proteolytic steps in MERS-CoV infection are required for the virus to overcome the resistance of its spike proteins to conformational changes that are induced by the target-cell receptor. These findings suggest that the first proteolytic steps in MERS-CoV infection are important for the virus to infect human cells, and therefore, they may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and thus on climate change. Increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals in catering outlets is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impact of the food system. This study shows that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering outlet increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 61.8% in the experimental study and by 78.8% in the observational study. This increase in vegetarian meals was sustained over the course of the year. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. This approach could be applied to other dietary choices, such as reducing the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages. It could also be applied to other sectors, such as the home, to increase the proportion of sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with its extracellular environment. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostic tests and vaccines. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. They also provide a foundation for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) and its receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxic increase in CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected CHO cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for thinking about the strengths of associations in complex datasets. The hope is that this will lead to better decisions about what to do with the associations that are found.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult to achieve, and the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for transplantation therapy. (Read more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of ALK and Ltk, respectively, has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTKs. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also provides a new model system for studying the role of RTKs in development and disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the molecular basis of insulin resistance is well-known, the role of STING in β-cell function and T2D is still unclear. Herein, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Moreover, we established the pathophysiological significance of STING in β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanism of STING in T2D. Furthermore, our study also suggests that STING might be a potential therapeutic target for T2D. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process in the life cycle of the virus, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disruption of local hemodynamics. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires in the United States over the past 2 decades. We show that human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of ignitions, and increasing management in regions where human-caused wildfires are dominant. These actions are likely to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Read less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. This may be useful for policymakers and urban planners who are interested in improving the quality of life in their cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. This may be useful for policymakers and urban planners who are interested in improving the quality of life in their cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe birth defects and neurological complications. The virus has spread rapidly across the globe, and there is a need to understand the factors that determine the course of the disease. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus grows rapidly within cells and that the time to detectable virus in the plasma is short. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of clinical trials for ZIKV. (Read more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. Here, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a hub for communication with the microbiome. We identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can trigger the growth of intestinal tumors. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the microbiome can trigger the growth of intestinal tumors. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumor growth. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and the majority of patients die. The identification of mechanisms that contribute to the development of resistance to treatment and the identification of new targets for therapy are therefore of critical importance. Here we identify the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 as a potential target for therapy.

The timing of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key event in the Earth system, but the cause of this change is still debated. Here we show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation likely led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a change in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a shift in the location of the Southern Ocean monsoon. These changes likely led to a change in the Southern Ocean circulation, which in turn led to accelerated deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a large impact on the climate system. (Read more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising candidate for this purpose, but the safety issue is still a major obstacle. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of Mo-based oxide is the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential. The full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the primary pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new approach for identifying genes and pathways that control regeneration in the adult CNS. Moreover, we show that this form of regeneration is triggered by a form of activity that is common to both regeneration and injury. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of new regenerative mechanisms.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the survival of individuals. In this study, we provide a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We show that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also show that the distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the mechanisms underlying these patterns are ancient and conserved. Finally, we show that the distribution of recombination is correlated with the distribution of gene promoters, suggesting that the distribution of recombination is a consequence of the distribution of genes. These results provide a detailed view of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant and may be useful for the study of recombination in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in the field of functional brain imaging. Here, we show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the DMN. In Parkinson’s disease, the DMN-like dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant networks in healthy subjects and PD patients during rest and during task performance. Network deactivation was reduced in early PD, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Network expression was associated with cognitive function in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the resting brain and its functional properties. They also suggest that the DMN may be a target for therapeutic interventions in neurodegenerative diseases. This work provides a new perspective on the study of the resting brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on tRNA and rRNA. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure on nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This is the first example of a 5′ modification in eukaryotes that is not found on tRNA or rRNA. The 5′ NAD+ cap structure may have a role in the regulation of gene expression.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that this association is maintained in monocytes from people with diabetes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of the disorder. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the flavor of tomato is a major factor in their appeal. The production of the diverse array of volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is poorly understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other classes of nitrogenous flavor compounds in plants. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. Here we show that these two factors interact to alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the need to consider the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in conservation and management. This is particularly important for tropical forests, where biodiversity loss and environmental warming are both high. Our results suggest that tropical forests are likely to be more vulnerable to the impacts of climate change than temperate forests.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to be involved in different aspects of navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be involved in the formation of a map of local space, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which are thought to be involved in the formation of a map of the environment. Our results suggest that grid cells may have a more specialized role in navigation. This work provides a detailed view of the organization of the navigation circuit in the MEC. It will be useful for understanding the function of the navigation circuit and for developing new treatments for navigational disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of the use of a parasite to study flowering.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of this disorder is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The dopamine system is also involved in a variety of other neurological disorders, including depression, schizophrenia, and addiction. Here, we describe a previously unknown type of neuron in the substantia nigra, the striosome, which is thought to be involved in these disorders. We show that the striosome is connected to the dopamine-producing neurons of the nigrostriatal pathway, and that the striosome is also connected to the dopamine-producing neurons of the nigrothalamic pathway. We also show that the striosome is connected to the dopamine-producing neurons of the nigrothalamic pathway through a specialized type of neuron, the striosome–dendron bouquet. These findings suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, and we use this sense to navigate our social lives. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by others to gauge connection, and it may be the key to understanding how we form and maintain social relationships.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate and are therefore critical for the regulation of cardiac output. SAN dysfunction is a hallmark of several cardiac diseases, including atrial fibrillation, which is the most common cardiac arrhythmia. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of the SAN by controlling the content of intracellular Ca2+ in the cardiomyocytes. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atrial fibrillation. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies for rice. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. This adaptive change in neuronal excitability is the substrate of memory and is the mechanism by which information is read back into the system. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of RNA-based therapeutics. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plant cells is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and provides a detailed assessment of the design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Lake Michigan is a valuable resource for the Great Lakes region and the United States. It is also a valuable sentinel for the impacts of nutrient loading on coastal ecosystems. We show that small tributaries of Lake Michigan are a significant source of nutrients to the lake, and that these nutrients are more bioavailable than those from larger tributaries. This finding suggests that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal eutrophication. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and the need to consider them in nutrient management efforts. This work provides a snapshot of coastal nutrient inputs from small tributaries, which can be used to assess the impacts of nutrient loading on coastal ecosystems and to develop management strategies to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading. This work also provides a baseline for future studies to assess the impacts of climate change on coastal nutrient inputs. (Read more)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a small initial condition for the universe is required to explain the observed large-scale structure. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the case of chemical networks.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in silico and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that this change can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers insights into the mechanisms of action of NMDAR-Abs, and may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients. This work may also help to explain the effects of other drugs that can change the dynamics of the brain, and may help to explain the effects of other drugs that can cause seizures. The Earth system has experienced abrupt warming events in the past, and it is important to understand how the system responds to such events. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a large injection of organic matter–derived carbon and widespread seafloor anoxia. We also present a modeling approach that can be used to investigate such events. This work provides insights into the Earth system response to abrupt warming events and can be used to investigate the response of the system to anthropogenic warming. This work also provides a link between the past and the present.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection.
