The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key factor in its survival and reproduction. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, sex is determined by the sex of the individual, and in species with multiple loci, sex is determined by the sex of the locus. Here we investigate the effects of multiple loci on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female-determining alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple loci can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a new sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple sex determination alleles in populations. (Read more)

The retina is challenged by a number of reactive species that can damage photoreceptors and the retinal pigment epithelium. We sought to understand how iron levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that iron levels impact the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a precursor of the damaging aldehyde-bearing species. These findings suggest that iron levels impact the redox state of the retina and may contribute to the photodamage of the retina. This interpretation is supported by the observation that iron chelation decreased the photodamage of the retina. These findings may have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (AMD). (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the functioning of the food web. In this study, we show that the evolution of the specialized feeding strategy of siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their tentacles. Our results contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization and morphological innovation in predators, and help us to understand the role of predators in food webs. This work also provides insights into the evolution of the food web itself.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The evolution of the modern human hand is a major area of debate, with the fossil record providing only fragmentary evidence. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene site of Kaitio, Kenya, that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Read more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon pool is a critical metabolic substrate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, which blocks colon cancer cell growth. We also report the discovery of a new class of glycine transporter inhibitors, which may be useful in the treatment of lymphoma. These studies provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The role of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and, in turn, their health and nutrition. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of forests in improving people’s diets and health.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show here that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
